intro: Abies religiosa subsp. colimensis, commonly known as the Sierra Madre fir, is a rare and endemic subspecies native to the Sierra Madre mountains in Mexico. It is a coniferous evergreen tree characterized by its conical shape and dense foliage. The needles are dark green, glossy, and arranged in spirals along the branches. It produces cone-like structures that contain seeds, typical of the Pinaceae family. This subspecies thrives in high-altitude environments with cool, moist climates and is adapted to the specific ecological conditions of its native range.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abies religiosa subsp. colimensis is primarily native to the Sierra Madre Occidental and the southern regions of the Sierra Madre del Sur in Mexico. This subspecies is found in the states of Sinaloa, Nayarit, Jalisco, and Oaxaca. It grows in high-altitude cloud forests, typically at elevations between 1,500 and 3,000 meters. The plant thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often associated with montane ecosystems. Its distribution is limited to specific geographic areas within these mountain ranges.
